properties.NAME: New York City Civil and Housing Court, Richmond County Branch
properties.DESCRIPTION: City Civil Courts hear civil cases involving amounts up to $25,000, and Housing Courts hear landlord-tenant disputes, including eviction cases. People involved with the criminal courts may find themselves in civil or housing court as well, since arrest and conviction can have repercussions for the housing of both the court-involved individual and their family.

properties.NAME: Midtown Community Court
properties.DESCRIPTION: The Midtown Community Court opened in 1993 to offer an alternative adjudication process for quality-of-life offenses like trespassing, panhandling, and marijuana possession. Located in Hell’s Kitchen, Manhattan, and overseen by the nonprofit Center for Court Innovation, the court hears about 20,000 misdemeanor and summonses cases per year originating from four nearby police precincts. With an emphasis on alternatives to incarceration, the court typically sentences offenders to community service and provides social services to address their underlying needs, such as mental health counseling and job training.

properties.NAME: New York City Criminal Court, Bronx County Branch
properties.DESCRIPTION: Handles misdemeanors (crimes punishable by fine or imprisonment of up to one year) and lesser offenses; also conducts arraignments and preliminary hearings for felonies (crimes punishable by imprisonment of more than one year). Defendants may be detained in holding cells until their hearing.

properties.NAME: Harlem Community Justice Center
properties.DESCRIPTION: Since 1993, the Center for Court Innovation has opened three Community Courts in New York City. Community Courts encourage the use of alternative sentencing and diversion programs to reduce incarceration, and attempt to connect at-risk individuals and families with resources.

properties.NAME: Red Hook Community Justice Center
properties.DESCRIPTION: Located in a refurbished Catholic school, this community court run by the nonprofit Center for Court Innovation opened in 2000 with a new approach to the court system, emphasizing alternatives to incarceration and unconventional programs. A single judge decides misdemeanors and summonses, family matters, and housing disputes for three police jurisdictions in southwest Brooklyn, covering approximately 200,000 people. Taking a problem-solving approach, the court decides cases in ways that recompense the community, address the needs of the victim, and aim to change the defendant’s behavior.

properties.NAME: Vernon C. Bain Center (VCBC)
properties.DESCRIPTION: Nicknamed “The Boat,” the Vernon C. Bain Center is a five-story barge docked in the East River at Hunts Point in the Bronx. The medium- and maximum-security jail has 800 beds in 16 dormitories. When VCBC opened in 1992 during intense prison overcrowding, the city had five maritime jails—including two former British troop carriers docked in Lower Manhattan and two converted Staten Island ferries docked at Rikers Island—as part of a policy under Mayor Ed Koch to develop facilities quickly while trying to avoid community opposition to new neighborhood jails. Today, it is the only floating jail in New York City and the largest facility of its kind in the world.

properties.NAME: Brooklyn Detention Complex (BKDC)
properties.DESCRIPTION: Intake facility and single-cell jail, housing men facing trial in Kings and Richmond Counties. BKDC was closed in 2003 due to declining jail populations, but reopened in 2012 after the decision to close several buildings on Rikers which had fallen into disrepair.

properties.NAME: Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) Brooklyn
properties.DESCRIPTION: Houses people who are arrested and detained by federal police, awaiting appearance before the US District Court for the Eastern District of New York.

properties.NAME: Bellevue Hospital Prison Ward (BHPW)
properties.DESCRIPTION: The Bellevue Hospital Prison Ward is a secure unit located on the 19th floor of the city-run Bellevue Hospital Center. The approximately 65-bed facility is for male inmates requiring acute psychiatric care or medical attention. Called the “forensic unit,” the ward includes a small courtroom to decide whether patient-prisoners can be treated against their will. The unit is staffed by the Department of Corrections and the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation. More than 40 percent of New York City’s inmates have been diagnosed with mental illness.

properties.NAME: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC)
properties.DESCRIPTION: Houses people who are arrested and detained by federal police, awaiting appearance before the US District Court for the Southern District of New York.

properties.NAME: Anna M. Kross Center (AMKC)
properties.DESCRIPTION: A 40-acre complex, the Anna M. Kross Center is the largest jail on Rikers Island with about 2,400 beds for male inmates spread across 40 housing areas. Opened in 1978, AMKC is named for the second female Commissioner of the Department of Corrections, who was responsible for “wiping out many of the dungeon-like features of the prison system,” according to her 1979 New York Times obituary. AMKC houses a large number of detainees with diagnosed mental illness, and contains the DOC’s mental health center and methadone detoxification unit.

properties.NAME: Eric M. Taylor Center (EMTC)
properties.DESCRIPTION: Houses approximately 1800 adolescent and adult males sentenced for terms of one year or less. Residents here are required to work, and make up much of the Rikers Island maintenance staff and ground crews.

properties.NAME: George Motchan Detention Center (GMDC)
properties.DESCRIPTION: GMDC was the Correctional Institution for Women before the 1988 opening of the Rose M. Singer Center, and has since been designated a men’s facility with 2,098 beds. GMDC houses 18- to 21-year-olds who are targeted for young-adult educational and mental health programming.

properties.NAME: George R. Vierno Center (GRVC)
properties.DESCRIPTION: 1,350-bed jail containing medical facilities and 150 air-conditioned solitary cells where people may be segregated for 23 hours per day, gradually reintegrating with the general population as they demonstrate “good behavior.”

properties.NAME: North Infirmary Command (NIC)
properties.DESCRIPTION: Houses inmates on Rikers who are sick but not sick enough to require hospitalization, inmates who require extreme protective custody, and inmates with HIV- or AIDS-related conditions.

properties.NAME: Otis Bantum Correctional Center (OBCC)
properties.DESCRIPTION: The Otis Bantum Correctional Center, opened in 1985, has 1,600 beds for male detainees on Rikers Island. OBCC includes the 400-bed Central Punitive Segregation Unit, better known as solitary confinement and nicknamed “the bing.” (New York City ended solitary confinement for inmates under 21 in 2016.) A 50-bed Enhanced Supervision Housing unit was opened at OBCC in 2015 as an alternative to punitive segregation for the most dangerous inmates, who must be escorted wherever they move throughout Rikers.

properties.NAME: Robert N. Davoren Complex (RNDC)
properties.DESCRIPTION: Houses 16- to 17-year-old boys and adult men in pre-trial detention.

properties.NAME: Rose M. Singer Center (RMSC)
properties.DESCRIPTION: Known as “Rosie’s,” the Rose M. Singer Center is Rikers Island’s only women’s jail, housing both adult women and adolescent girls. Named for one of the original members of the city’s Board of Correction, the facility opened in 1988 with 800 beds. It has been expanded to hold more than 1,100 beds. With a rise in female inmates, in 1985 the city opened the country’s first jail-based nursery at the former Correctional Institution for Women. Today, the 25-bed nursery is housed at Rosie’s for women who give birth while detained or, for those that qualify, who bring their newborns in after booking.

properties.NAME: West Facility (WF)
properties.DESCRIPTION: Was a 940-bed jail including a 140-bed, air-conditioned contagious disease unit for people with diseases like tuberculosis. Currently only the contagious disease unit is in use.

properties.NAME: Elmhurst Hospital Prison Ward (EHPW)
properties.DESCRIPTION: The Elmhurst Hospital Prison Ward is a secure unit within the city-run Elmhurst Hospital Center. The approximately 15-bed facility is for female inmates requiring acute psychiatric care, staffed by the Department of Corrections and the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation. More than 40 percent of New York City’s inmates have been diagnosed with mental illness.

properties.NAME: Queensboro Correctional Facility
properties.DESCRIPTION: Intake facility and jail, housing men facing trial in Queens County.

properties.NAME: James A. Thomas Center (JATC)
properties.DESCRIPTION: Previously a men's jail, JATC was shut down in 2000 due to asbestos.

properties.NAME: Queens Detention Facility
properties.DESCRIPTION: Private jail, previously contracted to house immigrant detainees for Immigration and Customs Enforcement; since 2005, it has been operated by GEO Group (a private company) to house primarily pre-sentencing detainees for the US Marshals Service.

properties.NAME: Edgecombe Residential Treatment Facility
properties.DESCRIPTION: Houses 110 people on parole who voluntarily stay in this minimum security residential substance-abuse and addiction treatment program for 10-45 days, before returning to community life.

properties.NAME: Lincoln Correctional Facility
properties.TYPE: Minimum Security and Work Release Prison
properties.DESCRIPTION: Nonviolent offenders who are sentenced to Lincoln, a work release facility, may spend a significant amount of time outside its walls. Some may be housed at the prison a few days out of each week. Others may spend the majority of their sentenced time working and living off-site, and report to the prison only periodically, whether each day or once or twice a week, to take a urine test or speak with a counselor.

properties.NAME: Rose M. Singer Center (RMSC)
properties.DESCRIPTION: Known as “Rosie’s,” the Rose M. Singer Center is Rikers Island’s only women’s jail, housing both adult women and adolescent girls. Named for one of the original members of the city’s Board of Correction, the facility opened in 1988 with 800 beds. It has been expanded to hold more than 1,100 beds. With a rise in female inmates, in 1985 the city opened the country’s first jail-based nursery at the former Correctional Institution for Women. Today, the 25-bed nursery is housed at Rosie’s for women who give birth while detained or, for those that qualify, who bring their newborns in after booking.

properties.NAME: Bellevue Hospital Prison Ward (BHPW)
properties.DESCRIPTION: The Bellevue Hospital Prison Ward is a secure unit located on the 19th floor of the city-run Bellevue Hospital Center. The approximately 65-bed facility is for male inmates requiring acute psychiatric care or medical attention. Called the “forensic unit,” the ward includes a small courtroom to decide whether patient-prisoners can be treated against their will. The unit is staffed by the Department of Corrections and the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation. More than 40 percent of New York City’s inmates have been diagnosed with mental illness.

properties.NAME: North Infirmary Command (NIC)
properties.DESCRIPTION: Houses inmates on Rikers who are sick but not sick enough to require hospitalization, inmates who require extreme protective custody, and inmates with HIV- or AIDS-related conditions.

properties.NAME: West Facility (WF)
properties.DESCRIPTION: Was a 940-bed jail including a 140-bed, air-conditioned contagious disease unit for people with diseases like tuberculosis. Currently only the contagious disease unit is in use.

properties.NAME: Elmhurst Hospital Prison Ward (EHPW)
properties.DESCRIPTION: The Elmhurst Hospital Prison Ward is a secure unit within the city-run Elmhurst Hospital Center. The approximately 15-bed facility is for female inmates requiring acute psychiatric care, staffed by the Department of Corrections and the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation. More than 40 percent of New York City’s inmates have been diagnosed with mental illness.

properties.NAME: Kirby Forensic Psychiatric Center
properties.DESCRIPTION: Maximum security state facility. Defendants found not guilty for reason of insanity or mentally unfit to stand trial may be remanded to a psychiatric detention facility indefinitely. They can apply, but must be approved by the judge and the District Attorney’s office, to return home or to transition to less restrictive treatment. Some people remain in forensic psychiatric treatment for years or even decades, and some are detained longer than the sentence of the crime of which they were accused. This is a secure facility for people 16 years or older. This facility also administers sex offender counseling and treatment programs, and staff may conduct mental health evaluations of pre-trial detainees, defendants, and people who are currently incarcerated.

properties.NAME: Central New York Psychiatric Center (PC)
properties.DESCRIPTION: 220-bed, maximum security state facility for involuntary hospitalization. Defendants found not guilty for reason of insanity or mentally unfit to stand trial may be remanded to a psychiatric detention facility indefinitely. They can apply, but must be approved by the judge and the District Attorney’s office, to return home or to transition to less restrictive treatment. Some people remain in forensic psychiatric treatment for years or even decades, and some are detained longer than the sentence of the crime of which they were accused. This facility also administers sex offender counseling and treatment programs, and staff may conduct mental health evaluations of pre-trial detainees, defendants, and people who are currently incarcerated.

properties.DESCRIPTION: Defendants found not guilty for reason of insanity or mentally unfit to stand trial may be remanded to a psychiatric detention facility indefinitely. Some people remain in forensic psychiatric treatment for years or even decades, and some are detained longer than the sentence of the crime of which they were accused. This is a secure facility for people 16 years or older.

properties.DESCRIPTION: People who have been remanded to Forensic Psychiatric Detention but are approved to transition out of a secure institution may be court ordered to receive treatment at these facilities. properties.NAME: Harlem NeON
properties.DESCRIPTION: In 2012, New York City launched a reinvention of the probation office as part of a new strategic plan to keep people out of the criminal justice system. The Neighborhood Opportunity Network (NeON) centers are co-located with community organizations and provide social services and mentoring, transforming a visit to a probation officer into a visit to a friendlier and more productive “resource hub.”

properties.NAME: NYC Department of Correction Potter's Field
properties.DESCRIPTION: This 101-acre island in the Long Island Sound is New York City’s official potter’s field, the burial site for the indigent and unidentified. In use since 1869, the island holds more than one million bodies in unmarked graves. Largely inaccessible to the public, the island is overseen by the Department of Corrections and burials are carried out by inmates from Rikers Island who are assigned to “island duty.”

properties.NAME: Richmond County Clerk of the Supreme Court and Comissioner of Jurors
properties.DESCRIPTION: Receives filings, fines, and fees related to court cases. While the majority of the work of the Clerk’s office has to do with civil proceedings, criminal sentences may involve payment of a fine. Criminal justice-involved people may find themselves in violation of their sentence – and vulnerable to harsher punishment – if they are unable or fail to do so. This is also the Court Clerk office where jury and juror summons are administered.

properties.NAME: NYC Department of Corrections Headquarters
properties.DESCRIPTION: Administers jails in New York City, which are where people are taken when they are arrested and awaiting arraignment; when they have been arraigned, are awaiting trial, and have been remanded or cannot pay their bail; or when they have been sentenced to a term of incarceration less than one year.

properties.NAME: NYC Department of Probation
properties.DESCRIPTION: Administers probation in New York City, which is a form of criminal sentencing wherein incarceration is temporarily deferred, and, contingent on the fulfillment of the terms of the probation (such as performing community service, attending counseling, or passing drug tests), eventually voided.

Dinkins, the CCRB is an independent civilian oversight agency that hears and investigates complaints of abuse, misuse of authority, or excessive force against police officers. properties.NAME: Rikers Island Cogeneration Plant
properties.DESCRIPTION: This Cogeneration Plant provides heat and power to the facilities on Rikers Island.

properties.NAME: Rikers Island Food Waste Composting Facility
properties.DESCRIPTION: Composting Facility; Rikers Island generates 30-40 tons of food waste daily. Waste takes 20 days to pass through the facility, and then several months to cure outside. Finished compost is mainly used on Rikers.

properties.NAME: Rikers Island Organic Farm
properties.DESCRIPTION: Inmates work on this farm which is supplied with compost from the Food Waste Composting Facility, and which provides produce to City Harvest.
